Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Situation2: They develop a floor plan for a new office, ensuring workspaces accommodate employees’ needs efficiently.
Story: I stared at the blinking cursor on my laptop, the open floor plan for the new office half-finished. My phone buzzed again—another message from my stepbrother, reminding me about the family holiday trip tomorrow. “Don’t forget, Mom really wants you there,” he wrote. I could almost hear the hope in his words, the unspoken plea for me to be part of the family, to show up and belong. But the deadline for the office design loomed, and my boss had made it clear: the client expected a complete, functional plan by Monday. Every detail mattered—natural light, collaborative spaces, quiet zones. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in. My family wanted me present, laughing and sharing stories, while my team needed my focus and creativity. I wanted to be the reliable step-sibling, the one who didn’t disappoint, but I also wanted to be the architect who delivered excellence. My chest tightened as I glanced between the family group chat and the unfinished design, torn by the impossible choice between belonging and responsibility.
